p.s: To convince his readers, Worne uses different communicative strategies.
In the following, i'mI'm going to analyse these and explain his use of language in terms of arguments and structure.
Throughout the text several facts and statistics are employed.
For example, the decrease of people, studying foreign languages (l. 3) or the dropped amount of taken exams (l. 12), relate to statistics, which give the article more validity and credibility.
By showing numbers 10,000 fearer exams(l. 9), 1990(l. 10) the reader gets the impression of a good investigation.
On the other hand, Worne does not name any sources, which makes his statistics questionable.
In line twelve, an irony is used to refute possible counterarguments.

In a hyperbolic manner, he attrunes the perfectly intelligent people (l. 19), who believe that most people in global economic speaking englishEnglish, thus having an example of someone who believes the counterposition.
In this case, the irony indicates that this position is not perfectly intelligent but not reasonable, which supports his position.

Lastly, Worne uses his most powerful communicative strategy: Afterafter discussing the reasons for the steady decline(l. 11) of foreign languages, he appeals to the readers and offers a practicable solution (ll. 32-35) So parents... without us (ll. 32-35) By adressing the parents, the people who have a chance to change these tendencies get emotionalemotionally involved, and are likely to change their own view.
The metaphor of strings on a children's bow(ll. 34-35) emphasizes their responsibility.
The whole article pursues the intention of adressing the parents of the UK and influence them to educate their children in terms of cultural awareness / involvement.
Hence the author uses the enumerated stilisticstylistic devices to manipulate the reader.
Also the structure does support this intention.
An introduction adresses the problem (l. 1-12), the main-partmain part enumerates arguments for supporting foreign speakers and lastly the appeal is used to demand action.
So the reader gets subtlesubtly pushed in the direction of action.
